org.epics.util.time

Class Timestamp

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.epics.util.time.Timestamp
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<Timestamp>

    public class Timestamp
extends Object
implements Comparable<Timestamp>
    Represents a time stamp at nanosecond accuracy. The time is internally stored as a 64 + 32 bit value: number of seconds from the Java/UNIX epoch (1/1/1970) and the nanoseconds past that instant. The range is of 292 billion years before and another 292 past the epoch.

    Note that while TimeStamp are usually created according to system clocks which may take into account leap seconds, all the math operations on TimeStamps do not take leap seconds into account.

    JSR 310 compatibility

    This class is essentially equivalent to javax.time.Instant. When it will be released, the plan is to phase out this class in the same way that Date is going to be phased out. As of 2012/05/07, there are still multiple proposal on the table on that will work, but in all cases it requires having this class implement a single method interface and make all clients use that single method interface.
    Author:
    carcassi

      • getSec

        public long getSec()

      • getNanoSec

        public int getNanoSec()
        Nanoseconds within the given second.
        Returns:
        nanoseconds (0 < nanoSec < 999,999,999)

      • of

        public static Timestamp of(long epochSec,
           int nanoSec)
        Returns a new timestamp from Java/UNIX time.
        Parameters:
        epochSec - number of seconds in the Java/UNIX epoch.
        nanoSec - nanoseconds past the given seconds (must be 0 < nanoSec < 999,999,999)
        Returns:
        a new timestamp

      • of

        public static Timestamp of(Date date)
        Converts a Date to a timestamp. Date is accurate to milliseconds, so the last 6 digits are always going to be zeros.
        Parameters:
        date - the date to convert
        Returns:
        a new timestamp

      • now

        public static Timestamp now()
        Returns a new timestamp for the current instant. The timestamp is calculated using System.nanoTime(), so it has the accuracy given by that function.
        Returns:
        a new timestamp

      • toDate

        public Date toDate()
        Converts the time stamp to a standard Date. The conversion is done once, and it trims all precision below milliSec.
        Returns:
        a date

      • durationBetween

        public TimeDuration durationBetween(Timestamp time)
        Calculates the time between the reference and this timeStamp. The resulting duration is the absolute value, so it does not matter on which object the function is called.
        Parameters:
        time - another time stamp
        Returns:
        the duration between the two timeStamps

      • durationFrom

        public TimeDuration durationFrom(Timestamp reference)
        Calculates the time passed from the reference to this timeStamp. The result is the relative time from the reference to this timestamp, so that reference + result = this.
        Parameters:
        reference - another time stamp
        Returns:
        the duration from the reference to this
